importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on this date, marking the release of new research on ant colony architecture and disease resistance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study began in 2018 with social behavior observations, with the full architectural study extending into 2025, showing long-term research on ant responses to fungal pathogens.

keyTakeAways: Black garden ants (Lasius niger) modify their nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum.
Infected ants self-isolate, and healthy ants, especially nurses, increase distance from foragers — a form of proactive social distancing.
Nests exposed to the fungus become more compartmentalized, with reduced interconnectivity, farther spaced entrances, and longer travel routes.
These structural changes reduce disease transmission and work synergistically with social behaviors to protect the colony.
The findings represent the first documented case of a non-human social species actively modifying its environment to resist disease spread.
The research suggests principles of 'architectural immunity' can be applied to human public space design to reduce disease transmission.
The study was published in the journal Science and involves researchers Nathalie Stroeymeyt (University of Bristol) and Luke Leckie (Indiana University Bloomington).

summaryOfNewsArticle: Black garden ants (Lasius niger) have been found to modify their nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum. When infected, ants exhibit self-isolation and shift social behavior — such as healthy nurses distancing themselves from foragers — resembling proactive social distancing. Researchers Nathalie Stroeymeyt and Luke Leckie used CT scans to observe that infected colonies develop more compartmentalized nests with reduced tunnel connectivity, farther spaced entrances, and longer travel paths. These structural changes reduce disease transmission and work in tandem with social behaviors to protect vulnerable colony members. The study, published in the journal Science, represents the first demonstration of a non-human social species actively altering its environment in response to disease threats. Experts like Sarah Kocher suggest that these findings could inspire new approaches to human public space design, promoting 'architectural immunity' to help prevent disease spread.
title: Ants Design Colonies to Cut Disease Risk — Humans, Take Note!
